intro: If you are seeing this, something went wrong. Go to my Kaffie Hub profile instead.

post.body: This post was deleted and I have no idea what was written here. Probably something about hubs.
Well then... I somehow managed to accidentally join both hubs :\\ How do I fix this mess I've found myself in? There doesn't seem to be a way of leaving hubs, nor deleting posts/accounts.

Kaffie hurt herself in confusion! Lost 2 posts and several comments while trying to delete the blue profile. Please let me know if you see anything weird with my profile. I think I've got it sorted out a little.

Hmm... I was messing with the 'following' feature on the ZeroHello newsfeed. I wanted to abuse it to shove a simplified Kaffiene search in there, but it doesn't really work all that great. 

My tests worked somewhat, but entering a larger DB seemed to make the search lag out. There's also no easy way of sorting by rank. There's the possibility of abusing the date display, but I can't seem to make it display things newer than 'now'. And even then, it's not clean. And the actual searching itself isn't really that great. So much for that idea.

On the bright side, I did learn a lot about how databases worked on ZeroNet though, so that's a plus.
My favorite thing about ZeroMe is that it has reincarnated Facebook's old Stalker-box. I was so sad when Facebook killed it, but now it's here so I can stalk all of you people. :D
Fixed my pic, because when I first put it up I was lazy as hell. Apparently ZeroMe only supports 50x50 sized images. Super tiny.
That feel when you wake up in the morning and there's a ton of ZeroMe posts and comments to read. :D

Making a central post to discuss what actually happened. So back when I joined blue hub, I had mixed profiles. I initially fixed it by making blue hub's data.json just `{}` and pushing that. It worked, but it worked because I hadn't commented on a blue post.

Apparently, ZeroMe updates my blue hub comments in my blue hub folder, not my red hub. This is why my manually edited comment didn't show up, I put it in the red hub data.json. So it showed in the sidebar, but not on the post itself.

To fix, all I had to do was delete the data.json, and clear it out of the content.json, and sign+publish. It auto re-created the blue hub data.json with the proper posts. I then manually edited in the original glitched comment (and removed it from red hub) and everything's now working fine.

@nofish, is this the intended feature, or is my profile glitched somehow?

I was thinking that, given how wordy and long-written I am, that I should probably just make my own hub with a ridiculously high cap, so that I won't ever run out. It appears that many users are already starting to reach the half-way point for red/blue hub's size limit. And running my own hub would mean that I'm not subject to waiting to nofish to raise my limits. It'd also decentralize the userbase a bit more.

PSA for anyone who hasn't done so yet. Please unfollow my red hub profile, and follow my [new profile](/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Profile/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh/) and seed my [new hub that it's on](/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv), otherwise you won't be able to see my new posts. Thanks :)

comment.body: Well I joined red first. Worked fine. Then I went back to the 'create profile' screen (yay direct urls) and saw the 'join' button. So I clicked on join blue, and my stuff vanished temporarily and made a new profile. I refreshed and both popped up. If I delete the blue hub, my red data is the only thing that shows. If I delete the red hub, my blue data is the only thing that shows. I have no idea which one this comment is being published to...

This is what I see: https://ipfs.pics/ipfs/QmWpRgAMRG5M6id7fdtVQyBwpKUTU3iKkyrTqDfRMohFd1

You can see the default gradient profile picture in my blue hub auto post.
It's really upsetting :(
Hi. Also, I think I figured it out! Yay :D

It's not really important. It was literally the default 'hello zerome' post, and like one other with maybe 1 or 2 comments. Not a big deal at all. I'm just kinda bummed that I accidentally overwrote them, since I'm a usually a perfectionist.

Unfortunately I don't have any of the deleted posts backed up. I'm not in the habit of doing it, as I just care to get the latest online files for a site. It should be under my data folder, if you have a backup copy.

You can easily reproduce the error by going to the create page and clicking 'join' on blue. Then post something, and mess around with deleting and redownloading the hubs.

I'm on mac. I haven't really ever used Linux outside of a few times I tried the liveCDs. Should I try injecting some posts with lower counts, to see if we can get the comments (from other users) back? AFAIK, deleting my own posts shouldn't effect other people's comments, since they're signed with different keys.

Edit: Lookie there. I restored my previous red hub posts. Which were the Hello ZeroMe default, and something about hubs. I was right, the post content/date/etc. are all gone, but the comments from other users remained.

The only problem is that you'd need to be able to decrypt it. And since ZeroNet runs locally, that means anyone who'd want to snoop would still be able to, since they have the entire ZeroNet source code. They could also just make a clone site that displays all the data.

The important stuff to encrypt (non-public messages) is already encrypted. See ZeroMail.

Stalker-box (actually it was officially called 'ticker box') was pretty similar to ZeroMe's activity feed. It showed all of your friends' activity in real time with time stamps and everything.

You could see the pages they liked, what music (on spotify) they listened to, where they commented, what they posted, whether they uploaded/changed any pictures, etc. People were creeped out by it, and FB eventually removed it.

Yea, the UI is really sleek. TBH, All of the demo/official zites have really nice UI. It's honestly a huge part of what keeps me coming back.

Compare that to, say, IPFS. IPFS is a nightmare to use, but I love the idea.
I'd also like to know. I've just been clicking on everyone's page and looking at who they're following. But it'd be nice to have a list of people who are following you.

I don't really see the point. ZeroNet already suffers from inactivity and a lack of users. Private groups would reduce that further. Like a secret club inside a secret club. And having private sites sort of defeats the purpose of merger sites.

I do think it'd be interesting to have a private group chat system though. Especially as zeronet grows.

@Newuser123, huh? I can clearly see you're following @Katyab, and I'm very clearly not, since it doesn't show the green X, nor does @Katyab appear in my feed, ticker, or profile page. I'm also not following Splitfire, Razzo, ZAlex, Morpheus, etc. who are all listed here. Whereas on other pages it shows only a few.

Compare:

You: https://ipfs.pics/ipfs/QmRqkGZVkLYHcbNkHF3nta9iQmtyp6HvUCZrDeBUyUPPqb

Me: https://ipfs.pics/ipfs/QmbFtwFnwgKUDtY8KFvF2XXj31gfYaqokva6MddxjkQ528

tKarita: https://ipfs.pics/ipfs/QmeNkDEohmx6WwwKsfJQdQvUwsr1bzFpffxGGWhesvr2np

All different.
I didn't screencap the whole list. It goes down quite a bit. But yea, it doesn't look like it shows everyone. Just a lot. Maybe there's a cap on how many it shows?

Oh. No, the ones with the + are the one's *I'm* not following. In the screencap of the people you're following, I'm not following any of them. In the screencap of mine, I'm following all of them (obviously). It doesn't show in the screencap, but I actually see a mix. Like Bot and Scrub are green X's because I'm following them, but Emeraude and Skehmatics are + because I'm not.

That looks right to me. You're following everyone that you're following. You're following everyone that I'm following. And you're following everyone that tKarita's following, minus the glitched profiles.

Green/Grey circles relates to who you're following out of those listed on the page. The list itself under 'following' is who the person on the profile is following. So since you're following everyone (minus glitched profiles), then everyone should come with a green circle.
Just make another comment on the post of the comment you want to reply to. Much easier.

The content.json says '"max_size": 50000'. So... 50kb worth of stuff before you need it raised. I'm guessing once people start hitting the cap, a new hub will be made with a super high cap so we don't have to deal with nofish's iterative tiny cap increment shit.

Yea, that's definitely a problem. Personally, I think it's easier to just find the comments, than to have random posts refer to some vague unlinked comment that I forgot I wrote. I watch the activity feed like a hawk but I have the memory of a goldfish.

I think the best solution would be to have a notifications system, like every other modern social networking platform.

Yea, I get the purpose of a cap. It's just ridiculous to hit 20kb of text through like a few comments, and then have it raised to 100 where it's gonna run out shortly after. Like, they should start high, and decrease if you're spamming.
AFAIK, you have to just message the site operator (or in the case of zerome/merger sites, the hub operator).
Works fine for me...
Yea, but it downsizes it to 50x50 and makes it look awful. Cropping/resizing by hand makes the outcome much nicer.
Only time I fail is when I walk away from the computer :P. But yea, definitely needs a filter. Too many people just up and follow everyone, flooding the feed with 'X followed Y'.
Also: liking comments. I got too used to it from blogs and zerotalk, so it just feels weird to lack it now.

I'm talking about the size of the image stored in the data/users folder. My original pic was >400x400 and it downsized it to 50x50. Though, the pic was also not a square, so there's that. I just went ahead and did a pure 50x50 so no downsizes/scaling issues would happen.
It gives ZeroNet a more homely vibe. With ZeroTalk, I didn't really get a sense of community. But here it's thriving.
Bug? I'm having the same issue.
Yes and no. When you run across someone from another hub, it'll ask to download their hub. The 'everyone page' contains everyone from the hubs you're seeding.

I'm having an issue commenting on your post. Entering it in the comment box just hangs and doesn't ever submit anything. So I manually edited the data.json with the right format and submitted it that way, but now it's not showing up :(
Actually, I'm getting a lot of 'content publish failed' in general as well.
I accidentally everything :(

Hmm... I'm having problems commenting on either of your posts. I'm gonna go check some more blue hub users. I think the issue might be cross-hub commenting.

Edit: actually, you're commenting on mine just fine... Hmm...
Yea, I just confirmed. I only have issues with bluehub users. Red hub are fine.
Yea, infinity comments work

@Quadrangle, you have a similar data.json file in the red hub. Did you double hub, or is this literally just the default action? If so, It makes sense where all of my problems (including the mixed profile) came from. Joining a second hub makes the two hub's profile data conflicting, which isn't the intended functionality.
http://127.0.0.1:43110/kaffiene.bit
Well... so much for that. I had mine all formatted nice, and I frantically went to check when logged out. Sure enough, it lacks formatting and looks like garbage.
What would such a killer app be? I'm apparently awful at coming up with ideas.
Last I checked, infinity still has a 50kb cap. You gotta raise it to something like 1mb :P.

Go here (even while logged in): http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Create+profile

Just don't click 'join'.

I just realized that even if I made a new hub, I'm still subject to the other hubs' limits whenever I post on something in that hub. Perhaps we just need everyone to be on high-capacity hubs? I think I'm gonna go ahead and try to make a hub and see what happens. Prepare for things to break.
I'll do a write up after it's ready.
Here's the URL for my new hub. Please seed: http://127.0.0.1:43110/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/
The graphics glitch happened due to another user. Not me. The issue was a long name.

So it auto-downloaded the new hub data? And the old profile still shows all the right data? You should see the tutorial on how to switch hubs if everything's good. This post I intentionally made under red hub so that people could see it.

Yea. My redhub description says to unfollow/refollow. If you can see the long guide post (posted an hour ago) then you're able to see my new posts. This means that the new hub data is downloaded (since that's where it's hosted).

And yea, all hubs are publicly accessible. That's sort of the point. Anyone can join the Kaffie Hub either by joining it when they sign up, or by switching to it using the guide.

The old profile should point to the new one, but I was worried that anyone following my red hub profile before I switched wouldn't see the new posts. Hence the red hub profile intro and PSA. For best results, you'd want to unfollow the redhub profile and follow my Kaffie Hub one.

The hub site itself isn't a frontend like Infinity is. It's just a backend that can be used with any viewer.
I'd appreciate it if you threw my hub into your infinity front end (so it pops up by default). That way the users are a bit more decentralized, and my hub gets a bit more exposure as well.

Well, ZeroMe's hub page only shows Red/Blue unless you're seeding something else. And unless they clicked on my profile before signing up and selecting a hub, they likely picked red or blue. That's why I asked to have it as a default, so it appears for everyone and increases visibility. I just did a test to confirm this.

I literally just made an empty zeronet data folder to try it out. I made a nanasi account real quick, and then clicked 'create profile' on zerome. It only popped up red hub and blue hub with download links. Kaffie Hub and Infinity only popped up once I started seeding them and only under 'Seeded Hubs', not 'Default Hubs'. The default hubs (red/blue) are hard-coded into the ZeroMe content.json so that they'll always appear, even if unseeded.

But yea, Kaffie Hub/Infinity show up in the zerohello hub section *after* you already start seeding them. Which doesn't help for gaining users.

See?
Bluehub+Infinity Deleted but Red/Kaffie Dl'd: https://ipfs.pics/ipfs/QmRXwfgWMe9BkwtPuBsuaVom3eifjKTraxry5d8yYWHhG9

Everything DL'd except Bluehub: https://ipfs.pics/ipfs/QmVj9GqtMXREeSUZr35bUhPFHfRS9wfj6mNfDnRRKxhj2q

Everything Dl'd: https://ipfs.pics/ipfs/QmTC2zn7nFk5fPsxfGrhA3cbbTJmQUqwoE5DE7S5Gx3C3h

Edit: And when you start up fresh, only red/blue appear under the 'available hubs'.
Did you delete the hub before trying? I can't see the hub if I delete it. Obviously after you start seeding it, it'll appear in the 'hubs seeded' section. I'm talking about defaults.

Kaffie Hub has 5 user folders. 2 users (me and you), and 3 comments/likes.

I'm still unconvinced Kaffie Hub (or Infinity for that matter) appear as defaults. It doesn't appear when I delete the hub. It didn't appear for me with a fresh zeronet data folder. And not a single person has joined Kaffie Hub besides you, who already has the hub seeding.

I had to explicitly advertise my hub to get seeds. It didn't happen automatically at all. However, since I'm now using my hub, anyone who visits my profile will now download it in order to view my profile. Which then makes it pop up in the list.

The 'merged-hub' bit just lets ZeroNet know it's a hub, so that it may correctly incorporate it into merger sites. There's no way for ZeroMe to know about my hub unless I tell it. So there's no way for it to enter the default hubs unless it's either put there manually, or the default hubs does an auto-scrape (which defeats the purpose of a merger site). Perhaps the udb site could pull out a list of hubs and then use that. But AFAIK, ZeroMe doesn't do that.

Right. The only extra hubs (besides the defaults) that show are the ones you, yourself, are personally seeding. Someone who literally just came to ZeroMe won't have any extra hubs seeding, since they never visited a profile, and aren't the creator of said hub. So they'll choose red or blue (the defaults) and get stuck.

You saw your own, because you literally made it, so obviously you're seeding it and it'll pop up. However, literally everyone else, unless they're seeding your hub, won't see it in the list. As the screenshots I provided show. Instead, you have to manually enter the hubs into the 'default hubs' field on the viewer's content.json. The ZeroMe one looks like this: https://ipfs.pics/ipfs/QmQdnRpHNJpMCp9jxnbTVCKE57NwGzMxLj4EaB2gajwKG6

As you can see, neither my hub nor yours is listed.

@Bot, correct. The hubs work fine later on (for cross-hub posting and such), but you have to explicitly join these 3rd party ones. I didn't get any errors, since all I did was clone a hub. Your errors seem to stem from trying to make a viewer (like ZeroMe) the same site as a hub (like Redhub or Kaffie's hub). All a hub is, is some data with no code.

@Yuri, yea, there's a few ways to do this. We could easily make a 0list style site, or even just a plaintext list of links. I linked Kaffie Hub in my blog, for instance. We could also just clone ZeroMe and change the defaults, or write code to automatically display all the users' hubs. If you go look at the Kaffie Hub site, you'll see I made a splash page that explains how to join it. The big issue is catching users before they've settled into redhub or bluehub.

Nah, it's probably not important. I've gotten multiple confirmations that it doesn't really matter. As long as you can see the new hub posts (like the guide), then you're good to go. Following the new hub will indeed include the old posts. I just wasn't sure if the other way was true as well.

That, and I didn't want users stumbling onto my redhub page, since that could cause a mess down the line (with people being linked to both profiles). My redhub profile mentions to go to my new hub profile so everything should be good to go.
Posts (here and on ZeroTalk) use Markdown. So you can add a hyper link like this: [text of hyperlink](http://127.0.0.1:43110/urlhere)

These are great, but could we please get the ~1 line fix for the login issue? Just make the auto-login/profile page grab link to whatever is listed in 'hub', rather than whatever method you currently use. I find myself often logged into 1nfinity hub (even though I never registered there, and my data file there is identical to a regular non-home one), as well as red hub (I figured this was likely due to my old 'posts' section I didn't remove). It should be straight forward, and it'd fix a LOT of problems moving forward. Especially as people begin to make new hubs and foolishly click join on the 'create profile' page without editing the files.
I'd like a notification area of sorts. Kind of like how facebook and twitter have, that let you know about new replies that you haven't read yet.

Not sure why you posted your comment on this post (are you viewing my old profile, perhaps?), but yes. I already have kaffie.bit for my blog. And updating it took only like 0.005 namecoin. It cost me nothing. I don't really bother making a vanity address (like with the 1BLue or w/e) since it's not really a big deal. Namecoin works better.
Not yet, no.

Red hub and blue hub are sites with user data. ZeroMe merges the content of these sites and allows the users who are stored on them to interact with each other.

As of now, there's no difference between red and blue. They're just two separate sites to demonstrate the merging feature. If you want, you can only download red hub (since you're on red hub), and not have blue hub downloaded. Then you won't have to store the blue hub info, but you also won't see stuff happening on there. Instead, you'd only see red hub posts.

If you download both hubs, you can see the content from both.
I mostly read torrentfreak, and stuff on decentralization and futurology (not quite tech, but w/e). I think most people here have similar interests though :P

Actually, you can use a nanasi ID to generate  an ID that doesn't require a backend auth server. It just doesn't have unique names (the name is instead based on your public key):
http://127.0.0.1:43110/16KzwuSAjFnivNimSHuRdPrYd1pNPhuHqN/

That'd effectively allow it to be used on a mesh. The bigger issue is that there's no DHT support, meaning you need centralized trackers to find peers.

@Bashrc: I think another issue would be namecoin domain resolution. The .bit domains trace back to ZeroName, which has a centralized backend system for fetching the .bit registrations. There's a plugin that uses a local namecoin daemon. But on a mesh with no clearnet access you'd lose this functionality. Not a big deal, but it makes the UI a bit more clunky.

@ks: See nanasi. ZeroNet already generates a public/private key for each site you visit, based on your master seed. Nanasi uses this to generate a unique id for you, that you can access using your related private key. It's all local, and nothing goes to a backend. If you check out Kaffie@nanasi, you can see I made a post with no interaction w/ official zeronet stuff. And it popped up just fine due to how merger sites work. The downside with public key usage is that there's no way to guarantee unique readable usernames. Which is where namecoin came in. It stores names in the blockchain to guarantee uniqueness. But in a mesh, namecoin won't work, as there's no clearnet access to sync the blockchain.

Umm...
https://ipfs.pics/ipfs/QmU4sb95w7ZqXPphLxomU8vynr9gtcKEkRxidmfGEhga5a

Hub login is still horribly broken.
To be fair, 3 of those are mine :P
@Maomihz: To see anyone's hub, just hover over their name. Look at the url and look for /Profile/[hub]/[userid]/. The hub it says is what hub the user is.

You don't need to seed all the hubs if you don't want to. There's also stuff like different filesize restrictions, or being able to hold different data altogether.

The big reason is to decentralize. You can make any merger/viewer site work with the hubs. And you can make any hub work with the merger/viewer sites. So theoretically, a person could be on one hub and one viewer, and interact with someone that's using a different hub and a different viewer. But they can interact due to how merger sites work.

Unfortunately you can always trace the sites someone interacts with by looking up their public key in the site's data folder. You could encrypt their shopping info (what they buy for how much, etc) like in a zeromail kinda system. But you could still tell if someone was an active shopper somewhere.

Edit: For example, since you're on red hub, my comments here appear on the red hub under my public key. Even if they were encrypted. They aren't on my hub unless I comment on my hub. However, since you posted a top-level-post, it is stored in your hub, whereas mine will be stored in mine. The only way to avoid knowing that someone shops at a store, would be if they never posted data onto the store hub.
Worked like a charm on OSX/Firefox. I've been stressing about how to clean up the URL and even toyed with a custom protocol handler. This is much simpler. :D
@Scrub: Here's the link to the chrome extension: https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/zeronet-protocol/cpkpdcdljfbnepgfejplkhdnopniieop?utm_source=chrome-app-launcher-info-dialog
We definitely need a standardized way of linking. I think a custom protocol handler would be the way to do this, but I'm not sure it'd be compatible with every browser.

"missing js/list_mentions.coffee, js/all.js"

Doesn't do anything :\

There's been a few people to play around with webtorrent streaming. Fastcast is one that has a solid tech demo up and running. ZeroTube ran into similar problems as you: lack of streamers meant files would always have 0peers. I personally tried tweaking around with it, but it appears it's a bit to buggy with most browsers to make a solid streaming platform. I'd be curious if you actually end up making something neat with this. It definitely has potential.
It's way more active than ZeroTalk. Probably the most active site on ZeroNet, tbh.
yup.

I like how flexibile it is. You can easily clone sites, see the source code of things, and make your own spinoff if you don't like something. With merger sites you can now share content without needing to be in contact with major site developers. It truly puts the power back into the hands of the average browser.

Play uses regular rarbg torrents. For it to work with webtorrent, we'd need some webtorrent user seeding everything. Or rather, lots of them. What really needs to happen is widespread adoption of webtorrent so that the decentralized web can benefit from it.

This is the official help/faq cloned onto zeronet: http://127.0.0.1:43110/17Kom2G5qNDc6NaQwv445h1gFzxkY3ZtZe/

There's no other official resources besides that documentation.

WebTorrent doesn't work with regular torrent clients due to how WebRTC works. It can't communicate to anything other than other webrtc clients. The protocol itself is identical otherwise. Seed a torrent file with webtorrent (desktop) and both regular torrent clients, and webtorrent users can download it. The issue is the lack of people seeding for webtorrent users.
@Arsene Lupin: Nope. I just found it.

@Talnicrom: Technically you'd also need the user to sign in before you could do that. Otherwise you can't touch shit. Merging sites just makes a duplicate database of stuff in your local site's folder.

It is indeed possible to have a search function on a ZeroBlog. You just have to code it yourself.

It is indeed possible to clone ZeroTorrent. You just need to copy the files. The kickass torents zite did this: http://127.0.0.1:43110/1LBr1dHoXvJAMjDgW8Wcg5kbCoKyJnzo6p/

Python isn't needed at all, unless you're working on the ZeroNet software itself.

@Talnicrom: Not quite. Modifying merged-ZeroMe is useless. What you actually need to modify is the znet/data/[hubsite]/data/users/[userauthaddress]/data.json file. This is the file that's merged into the merger site database.

I'm unsure of what goes on behind the scenes to modify this file for hubs/merger sites. But I do know that you can't sign it without the user's cert. And to get that, you have to ask them to sign in, and have them explicitly agree to let the site sign stuff on their behind. No login = no damage.

Unless you can somehow manage to get the user's public and private key without their consent. But even then, you'd have to do every possible ID site, otherwise your thing could be thwarted with a nanasi/kaffie/zeroverse id.

But yes, once your site has access to their public and private key (only possible on your own site's data, or merged hub data) then you can modify it. For a good example, look at the ZeroMe clones. They can't touch your stuff (or even show it to you) until you select your cert and log in.

@Talnicrom: As I said, I haven't looked at the merger API at all, so I can't say how that all works.

As for the cert stuff, yes, that's correct. ZeroNet provides an authaddress and private key for each individual site for the user. This allows you to make unique IDs, or to switch authaddress/key to an ID site and match your cert. This lets you sign stuff on the site. To maliciously attack someone's zerome data, you'd have to have them select the cert they use on zerome on your site, so that you can use it to sign/modify their data (just as any merger site/zerome clone would).

I actually just started rewatching Mr Robot because I watched it quite a while ago and forgot everything by the time season 2 started airing. So now I'm almost done with season 1 again, and will likely move on to season 2 later tonight.
I dunno about zeronet alone. But something like bundling ZeroNet, IPFS, Tor, etc into one browser to make a decentralized super browser would be kinda neat.

You know, every time I see/hear/read/think stuff like this, my mind always jumps back to a mesh/p2p/zeronet easy-to-use os that disconnects entirely from the regular internet and makes it straight forward to jump onto mesh networks and to start new ones.
@Execin: Not just ZeroNet though. ZeroNet pushed through a mesh network. With stuff like Tox included for IM. Instant-setup internet that's fully decentralized out of the box.
So you're saying you can do @theterminator: and something will happen?

@Talnicrom: That's why we can't see them. The comments only show up if they're posted in the same hub as the post they're responding to. That is, red post comments in red hub, bot post comments in bot hub, etc. If you're just sticking all the comments in the bot hub, the only time they'll show up is if it's on a post that's in bot hub.
I get the failed publish message a lot, so I'm never sure if my posts go through. Right now for your profile intro I see your website: blog.musickiller.bit
Might be best to make specialized hubs for the various categories of torrents. So that the red/blue/green/etc hubs don't get filled up with just torrents.
In your data.json change "avatar" from 'generate' into either 'png' or 'jpg' depending on what you used.

>Avoid publish failed errors when using third-party id provier

What's the fix for this, exactly? I was under the impression that the publish fail errors were due to the other hub sites not having the permissions set, but apparently if you can fix it, then it's not.

@Jarmund: Should work right out of the box. The big issue of why videos don't play is because it's just me and @Sirenyc: seeding stuff. Sirenyc has a pretty slow connection (I was getting 50kb/s from him) which isn't enough to stream a video. And my seeding has been on the fritz, as webtorrent-desktop lags for me, and vuze seems to refuse to seed consistenty. If you could help seed stuff, that'd be amazing.

Edit: You do need webrtc on your browser. So be sure to enable it if you disabled it at some point. And be sure to use a webrtc-compatible browser like chrome or firefox.
@Jarmund: Hmm... Opera seems to not work well. Try searching for 'George Thorogood - I Drink Alone' or 'Sintel'. Those are videos that should always have a seed.

@Funkysquirrel: They're usable if you have configured your browser to use them. The most straight forward way is to just grab the chrome extension. However, over on [Kaffie.bit](http://127.0.0.1/kaffie.bit/test.html) you can grab the .pac and set that up as a local host proxy. That method works for all browsers.

@Heathenman: I made hub.kaffie.bit. Functionality-wise, it doesn't differ from the default hubs. It does have a raised file size limit, so that you aren't limited in how much you can post there. It's also helpful to decentralize the data, which is one of the main reasons there's hubs in the first place. Hubs themselves are all 'merged' into zerome, so that regardless of the hub you made a profile on, you can see posts made on other hubs.

@Heathenman: Sort of. The list of users is managed by a site owned by nofish. It's another sort of hub. You can't see *posts* if you aren't seeding a hub (such as the 'everyone' section). Nor can you see the profile of a user who's hub you aren't seeding. But in the list of users, everyone should show up, regardless of hub.

Edit: Hubs themselves are treated like sites. They have a single owner, but are hosted by visitors of the hub.
